[[Mentioned in Despatches]] |laterwork=Principal, [[Australian Administrative Staff College]] (1960–64) }} [[Lieutenant General (Australia)|Lieutenant General]] '''Sir Alwyn Ragnar Garrett''', [[Order of the British Empire|KBE]], [[Order of the Bath|CB]] (12 February 1900 – 4 November 1977) was a senior commander in the [[Australian Army]]. He served as [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of the General Staff]] (CGS) from 1958 to 1960. Born in [[Western Australia]], Garrett graduated from the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in 1921. He was [[adjutant]] and [[quartermaster]] in several [[regiment]]s of the [[Australian Light Horse]] before undertaking staff training in England, which he completed just as the Second World War broke out. Garrett joined the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]] soon afterwards, and commanded the [[2/31st Battalion (Australia)|2/31st Battalion]] in England before seeing action with Australian [[brigade]]s in [[Battle of Greece|Greece]] and [[Battle of Crete|Crete]] in 1941. Promoted to [[colonel]] the following year, he held senior staff positions with [[I Corps (Australia)|I Corps]] in [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]] and [[II Corps (Australia)|II Corps]] on [[Bougainville Campaign|Bougainville]] in 1944–45. He was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] for his staff work. After the war, Garrett served two terms as commandant of the [[Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff|Staff College, Queenscliff]], in 1946–47 and 1949–51. Between these appointments he was posted to Japan with the [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force]]. Promoted [[major general]], he became [[General Officer Commanding]] (GOC) [[5th Military District (Australia)|Western Command]] in August 1951, and [[Deputy Chief of Army (Australia)|Deputy Chief of the General Staff]] in January 1953. He took over Southern Command as a [[lieutenant general]] in October 1954, and was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1957. As CGS from March 1958, Garrett focused on rearmament and reorganisation, initiating the Army's short-lived restructure into a "[[Pentropic organisation|pentropic]]" formation. He was [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire|knighted]] in 1959. After retiring from the military in June 1960, Garrett became [[Honorary Colonel]] of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]], and was principal of the [[Australian Administrative Staff College]] until 1964. He died at [[Mornington, Victoria|Mornington]], Victoria, in 1977. ==Early life== Born on 12 February 1900 at [[Northam, Western Australia|Northam]], Western Australia, Alwyn Ragnar Garrett was the son of accountant Alwyn Garrett and his Swedish wife Maria Carolina (''née'' Wohlfahrt). Ragnar attended [[Guildford Grammar School]] before entering the [[Royal Military College, Duntroon]], in 1918. He graduated in 1921 and was posted to the [[Australian Light Horse]] as a [[lieutenant]].{{cite web|url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/A140282b.htm |title=Garrett, Sir Alwyn Ragnar |work=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|last=Grey|first=Jeffrey|accessdate=14 May 2015}}''The Army List'', p. 439 In December 1922, Garrett served as an extra [[aide-de-camp]] to the new [[Governor of South Australia]], General [[Tom Bridges|Sir Tom Bridges]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63747799 |title=Citizens' fine tribute |newspaper=[[South Australian Register|The Register]] |date=7 December 1922 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=9 }} He was appointed [[adjutant]]/[[quartermaster]] of the [[23rd Light Horse Regiment (Australia)|23rd Light Horse Regiment]] in November 1922. In November the following year he was seconded to the [[British Army]], and spent the next twelve months attached to the [[2nd Dragoon Guards (Queen's Bays)|2nd Dragoon Guards]] in [[Bangalore]], India.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article129310300 |title=Among the soldiers |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)|The News]] |date=19 November 1923 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=3 }} On his return to Australia in January 1925, Garrett was reappointed adjutant/quartermaster of the 23rd Light Horse.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article129828421 |title=Among the soldiers |newspaper=The News|date=23 February 1925 |accessdate=14 May 2015 |page=9 }} He married Shirley Lorraine Hunter, a nurse, on 9 September at St Peter's Anglican Church in the [[Adelaide]] suburb of [[Glenelg, South Australia|Glenelg]]; the couple had a son and a daughter. Garrett became adjutant/quartermaster of the [[9th Light Horse Regiment (Australia)|9th Light Horse Regiment]] at [[Jamestown, South Australia|Jamestown]], South Australia, in February 1926. He was promoted to [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]] in November 1929.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43915418 |title=Military social |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |date=10 March 1926 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=20 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128874276 |title=Naval and military |newspaper=The News |date=25 November 1929 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=8 }} In March 1930, Garrett was posted as adjutant/quartermaster to the [[3rd Light Horse Regiment (Australia)|3rd Light Horse Regiment]] at [[Mount Gambier, South Australia|Mount Gambier]], South Australia.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article73797585 |title=Militia training |newspaper=The Advertiser |date=7 March 1930 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=24}} As a speaker at Mount Gambier's [[Anzac Day]] commemorations on 25 April 1934, he was reported as warning of the poor state of Australia's preparedness for war, admonishing: "We shall not have the time that we had before the last war, and we shall not be fighting for our homes thousands of miles away. We shall be fighting at our own back door. That is what we have to prepare for."{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article77962369 |title=Diggers' re-union social |newspaper=[[The Border Watch]]|date=28 April 1934 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=7 }} In August that year he was transferred to the [[4th Light Horse Regiment (Australia)|4th Light Horse Regiment]] at [[Warrnambool]], Victoria, as adjutant/quartermaster.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article35124913 |title=Army and Navy notes |newspaper=The Advertiser |date=3 August 1934 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=11 }} Garrett was posted to the staff of Army Headquarters, [[Melbourne]], in March 1936, and departed for England in November the following year to attend the [[Staff College, Camberley]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article11126428 |title=Personal |newspaper=[[The Argus (Melbourne)|The Argus]] |date=23 November 1937 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=4 }} He was promoted to [[major]] in July 1938, and returned to Australia upon the [[Military history of Australia during World War II|outbreak of the Second World War]]. ==Second World War== [[File:KandaSurrender.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.28|Brigadier Garrett standing next to Lieutenant General [[Masatane Kanda]] at the Japanese surrender ceremony on Bougainville, 8 September 1945]] Garrett joined the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]] in November 1939, and was appointed [[brigade major]] of the [[18th Brigade (Australia)|18th Brigade]] under Brigadier [[Leslie Morshead]] in January 1940.Long, ''To Benghazi'', pp. 44, 48 The brigade departed for the [[Mediterranean and Middle East theatre of World War II|Middle East]] in May but, owing to the military situation following the [[Fall of France]], it was diverted to Britain, arriving in June.Long, ''To Benghazi'', pp. 85–86 Garrett was promoted [[lieutenant colonel]] on 16 September and took command of the [[2/31st Battalion (Australia)|2/31st Battalion]] the same day; he handed over the battalion to [[Selwyn Porter]] in February 1941, and departed England for the Middle East.Pratten, ''Australian Battalion Commanders in the Second World War'', p. 327 He saw active service with the [[19th Brigade (Australia)|19th Brigade]] and Savige Force in [[Battle of Greece|Greece]] and [[Battle of Crete|Crete]], under Brigadier [[Stanley Savige]]. Returning to Australia, Garrett was promoted to temporary [[colonel]] in April 1942 and became senior operations officer in the [[1st Armoured Division (Australia)|1st Armoured Division]], which served as a garrison force in case of Japanese invasion.{{cite magazine |last=Lambert |first=Zach |title=The Birth, Life and Death of the 1st Australian Armoured Division |date=Autumn 2012 |magazine=Australian Army Journal |page=93 |url=http://www.army.gov.au/~/media/Army/Our%20future/Publications/AAJ/2010s/2012/AAJ_2012_1.pdf}} He was posted to Army Headquarters, Melbourne, in October as Director of Armoured Fighting Vehicles. In September 1943, Garrett was appointed General Staff Officer Grade 1 (Operations) of [[I Corps (Australia)|I Corps]] under Lieutenant General [[Edmund Herring|Sir Edmund Herring]] in [[New Guinea campaign|New Guinea]].Dexter, ''The New Guinea Offensives'', p. 279 Three months later he was promoted temporary [[brigadier]] and became Brigadier General Staff of I Corps. He continued to serve in that position as I Corps was redesignated [[II Corps (Australia)|II Corps]] in April 1944, [[New Guinea Force]] the following month, and finally II Corps again in October 1944 for the campaign on [[Bougainville Campaign|Bougainville]] under Lieutenant General Savige.Dexter, ''The New Guinea Offensives'', pp. 780, 788Long, ''The Final Campaigns'', pp. 24–25, 97 Garrett was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] for his "skill, direction, and supervision" in having "prepared and guided all staff work to meet every conceivable requirement in the complete reorganisation of forces in New Guinea"; the honour was promulgated in ''[[The London Gazette]]'' on 19 July 1945.{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/965634 |title=Awards for service in Papua-New Guinea| work=The Argus|date=20 July 1945|page=6|accessdate=14 May 2015}}{{LondonGazette |issue=37184 |date=19 July 1945 |startpage=3715|supp=yes |accessdate=14 May 2015}} He was responsible for interrogating the first Japanese peace envoy to make contact with the Australians on Bougainville, on 18 August 1945, and was present when the instrument of surrender was signed on 8 September.Long, ''The Final Campaigns'', pp. 557–558James, ''The Hard Slog'', pp. 253–254 In November 1945, Garrett took command of the [[8th Brigade (Australia)|8th Brigade]] in New Guinea.{{cite web|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1026000/?image=3#display-image|title=8 Infantry Brigade November–December 1945|work=2nd Australian Imperial Force and Citizen Military Forces unit war diaries|page=3|publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]]|accessdate=18 May 2015}} He oversaw the brigade's return to Australia prior to its disbandment in March 1946.{{cite web|url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1021826/?image=88#display-image|title=8 Infantry Brigade January–March 1946|work=2nd Australian Imperial Force and Citizen Military Forces unit war diaries|page=88|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=18 May 2015}} His "exceptional service in the field" in the [[South West Pacific theatre of World War II|South West Pacific Area]] earned him another [[mention in despatches]], which was gazetted on 6 March 1947 and backdated to 2 November 1946.{{cite web|url=http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/items/ACCNUM_LARGE/RCDIG1068958/RCDIG1068958--11-.JPG|title=Recommendation: Mention in despatches|publisher=Australian War Memorial|accessdate=14 May 2015}}{{LondonGazette |issue=37898 |date=6 March 1947 |startpage=1091|supp=yes |accessdate=14 May 2015}} ==Post-war career== [[File:Brig. Garrett & Lt. Gen. Robertson - BCOF (1947).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.28|Brigadier Garrett (left) with [[John McCauley|Mrs McCauley]] and Lieutenant General [[Horace Robertson|Robertson]] (right) at the Officers Club, Headquarters BCOF, Japan, c. 1947|alt=Two uniformed men talking to a woman at a dinner table]] Following a three-month course at Staff College, Camberley, Garrett was appointed commandant of the [[Army Command and Staff College, Queenscliff|Staff College, Queenscliff]], Victoria, in June 1946. He was posted to Japan in March 1947, becoming Brigadier-in-Charge of Administration for the [[British Commonwealth Occupation Force]] in July. The size and scope of the occupation declined considerably during his tour, which finished in October 1949. Approximately 2,400 Australians, most from the [[67th Battalion (Australia)|67th Battalion]], remained by late 1948, compared to 11,000 in October 1946.Palazzo, ''The Australian Army'', p. 201Grey, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 164–166 In December 1949, Garrett resumed command of the Staff College, Queenscliff. Promoted temporary [[major general]], he was appointed [[General Officer Commanding]] (GOC) [[5th Military District (Australia)|Western Command]], which covered the state of [[Western Australia]], in August 1951.Palazzo, ''The Australian Army'', p. 224 He became [[Deputy Chief of Army (Australia)|Deputy Chief of the General Staff]] in February 1953. In December 1953, Garrett succeeded Major General [[Eric Woodward]] as Adjutant-General and Second Military Member of the Military Board.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48931449 |title=Army changes |newspaper=The Advertiser |date=20 October 1953 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=6 }} He was promoted temporary [[lieutenant general]] in October 1954 and appointed GOC Southern Command, which covered [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[South Australia]], and [[Tasmania]] and was, as of April 1953, the superior headquarters for several major [[Australian Army Reserve|Citizen Military Forces]] (CMF) formations including the [[3rd Division (Australia)|3rd Infantry Division]], the [[4th Brigade (Australia)|4th]] and [[6th Brigade (Australia)|6th Infantry Brigades]], the [[2nd Armoured Brigade (Australia)|2nd Armoured Brigade]], and two artillery groups.Palazzo, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 224, 238 His elevation to lieutenant general was made permanent in December 1954. Garrett was appointed a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in the [[Queen's Birthday Honours]] on 13 June 1957.{{LondonGazette |issue=41090 |date=13 June 1957|startpage=3407|supp=yes |accessdate=14 May 2015}} He succeeded Lieutenant General [[Henry Wells (general)|Sir Henry Wells]] as [[Chief of Army (Australia)|Chief of the General Staff]] (CGS) on 23 March 1958.{{cite media release |url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/search/display/display.w3p;query=Id%3A%22media%2Fpressrel%2FHPR01001879%22|title=Chief of the General Staff – extension of service|author=[[Minister for Defence (Australia)|Minister for Defence]]|date=7 May 1959|accessdate=30 March 2016}} Garrett was raised to [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in the 1959 [[New Year Honours]].{{LondonGazette |issue=41590 |date=1 January 1959 |startpage=38|supp=yes |accessdate=14 May 2015}} The Army underwent significant change during Garrett's term as CGS. In March 1959, he chaired the first meeting of the Military Board at the new Army Headquarters in [[Canberra]], following its move from Melbourne.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103093608 |title=Military Board in new headquarters|newspaper=[[The Canberra Times]]|date=7 March 1959 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=3 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article103127850 |title=Second Army move begins next Monday |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=12 August 1959 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=23 }} That August, he announced to his senior officers a radical reorganisation of the Army that would strengthen the regular forces and reduce reliance on the CMF, which since [[Federation of Australia|Federation]] had formed the backbone of Australia's military. This plan included the abolition of [[National Service Act 1951|National Service]], to which the Federal government had already agreed, and the introduction of a "[[Pentropic organisation|pentropic]]" divisional structure.Horner, ''Strategic Command'', pp. 176–177 Garrett championed the pentropic structure to overcome what he saw as the weakness of the traditional battalion for overseas deployments, and to ensure compatibility with the [[US Army]]'s [[pentomic]] formations. The Australian Army's traditional "triangular" divisional structure of three infantry battalions under a brigade headquarters was to be replaced with an organisation consisting of five larger battalions (hence "pentropic") without a brigade layer between division and battalion headquarters.Grey, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 204–207 The plan was opposed by CMF officers as it would result in the disbandment of the citizens' brigades and many of the old militia battalions. Under the new structure the CMF would not only shrink, its units would lose traditional ties to local communities through the establishment of new multi-battalion state-based regiments, leading to suspicions that the entire process was designed to demolish the CMF.Palazzo, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 257–258 {{Quote_box |width=27.7% |align=right |quote=In future, the Regular Army will be supported by the non-regular forces and not the reverse as at present. |source=—Lieutenant General Garrett, 22 December 1959 Palazzo, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 229, 419 }} Garrett was concerned not only with changing the Army's organisation but with upgrading its equipment; by the early 1960s the Army would acquire the [[FN FAL|FN 7.62mm rifle]], the [[M60 machine gun]], the [[M101 howitzer|M101 105mm howitzer]], the [[M113 armoured personnel carrier]], and new mortars and radios. He also advocated strongly for the Army to operate its own helicopters and light aircraft; the [[Australian Army Aviation Corps]] was eventually established in July 1968.Horner, ''Strategic Command'', pp. 295, 302 Garrett was scheduled to retire from the Army on his sixtieth birthday in February 1960 but the government extended his term. He retired on 30 June 1960 and was succeeded by Lieutenant General [[Reg Pollard (general)|Reg Pollard]], whom Garrett had recommended for the post in the face of opposition from the [[Department of the Army (Australia)|Minister for the Army]], [[John Cramer (Australian politician)|John Cramer]], who had attempted to appoint Major General [[Ivan Dougherty]], a retired CMF officer.Horner, ''Strategic Command'', pp. 194–195 Although Garrett's proposed reorganisation of the Army along pentropic lines went ahead under Pollard, it proved short-lived. The US Army abandoned the system in June 1961, and the Australian Army returned to the triangular formation following a review commissioned by Pollard's successor as CGS, Lieutenant General [[John Wilton (general)|Sir John Wilton]], in October 1964.Grey, ''The Australian Army'', pp. 209Dennis et al, ''Oxford Companion to Australian Military History'', pp. 419–420 ==Retirement== Upon retiring from the military, Garrett became principal of the [[Australian Administrative Staff College]], a private institution delivering courses to senior business and government personnel at [[Mount Eliza, Victoria|Mount Eliza]], Victoria.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dS9WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QuYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1896%2C2368708|title=Garrett to Head Staff College|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=5 January 1960|page=7|accessdate=28 March 2016}} During his four-year tenure, he lobbied for the reintroduction of conscription, and when the Federal government brought in a new [[National Service Act 1964|selective service scheme]] in 1965, he was invited to draw the first ballot of names.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article104286291 |title=Army call-up suggestion |newspaper=The Canberra Times |date=6 November 1963 |accessdate=19 May 2015 |page=20 }}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article105860929 |title=First 1966 call-up draw tomorrow |newspaper=The Canberra Times|date=9 September 1965 |accessdate=18 May 2015 |page=14 }} Garrett also advocated that the Army should have a division ready for war at all times.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article104286180 |title=Defence spending 'should increase' |newspaper=The Canberra Times|date=5 November 1963 |accessdate=19 May 2015 |page=3}} He served as [[honorary colonel]] of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]] and the [[Royal Western Australia Regiment]] from 1960 until 1965, when he was appointed Chairman of the Western Australian Coastal Shipping Commission, a position he held until 1970. He died on 4 November 1977 at [[Mornington, Victoria|Mornington]], Victoria, and was cremated. His wife had died earlier, and he was survived by his two children. ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * {{cite book|date=1 August 1956| title=The Army List of Officers of the Australian
